TfLiteImageClassification Info This sample needs camera permission. This device doesn\'t support Camera2 API. NN:On NN:Off Use NNAPI tflite NNAPI Threads: <<<<<<< HEAD Take a Photo =======
Learn about the Skin Conditions Basal cell carcinoma: A type of skin cancer that begins with basal cells. This form typically appears as a flesh-coloured bump with transparent borders on the skin, sometimes with scars. The main cause is prolonged exposure to sunlight or UV rays.\n Source: https://dermatology.ca/public-patients/skin/basal-cell-carcinoma
Melanoma: A type of skin cancer that occurs when the pigment producing cells that give colour to the skin become cancerous. The most dangerous form of skin cancer, these cancerous growths develop when skin cell DNA is damaged and trigger mutations. The main cause of melanoma is prolonged exposure to sunlight or UV rays. People who are fair-skinned, who gets sunburns easily or have a family history of melanoma are more likely to develop it.\n Source: https://dermatology.ca/public-patients/skin/melanoma
Actinic keratosis: A pre-cancerous area of thick, scaly, or crusty skin. These growths usually develop after prolonged exposure to sunlight or UV rays. They may develop into squamous cell carcinoma if left unchecked. People with Actinic keratosis are also likely to develop basal cell carcinoma and melanoma.\n Source: https://dermatology.ca/public-patients/skin/actinic-keratoses
Dermatofibroma: A common benign fibrous nodule often arises on the skin of the lower leg. They are rarely painful and have no other ill effects Dermatofibroma lumps do not away on their own; they can be surgically removed.\n Source: https://www.health.harvard.edu/a_to_z/dermatofibroma-a-to-z Melanocytic Nevi: More commonly known as a mole, these growths are composed of pigmented cells called melanocytes. They can be dark brown, yellow or flesh-coloured. The vast majority of moles that a person has appears during childhood and adolescence, though more may growth in adulthood. Most moles are benign, but some moles can be cancerous and may develop into melanoma. These moles are called dysplastic nevi. They are usually larger and more irregular than normal moles. They can be of mixed colours, are usually and irregular shape and grow noticeably over time.\n Source: https://www.health.harvard.edu/a_to_z/moles-nevi-a-to-z Pyogenic granulomas: These are non-cancerous skin growths that are small, round and usually blood red in color. They tend to bleed because they contain a large number of blood vessels. These skin growths mainly develop in children and young adults. The main cause is unknown, but they usually occur after an injury, and are easily infected. They can be surgically removed. Source: https://www.healthline.com/health/pyogenic-granuloma Seborrheic Keratoses: These are non-cancerous growths on the skin. They usually have an oily, crusty look, and can be tan, brown or black in colour. They are generally harmless, and are mostly found in the aging and elderly. They do not go away on their own. They can be surgically removed. Source: https://www.health.harvard.edu/a_to_z/seborrheic-keratoses-a-to-z
